posts.name: Carmine
posts.cooked: For the 2025-2026 season, I will be the 2022's electrical lead. I was wondering if anyone had some specific tips or tricks regarding teaching, wiring, etc. Anything you have to give would be much appreciated. Thanks!

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked:
These seem like low-hanging fruit, but these are simple things teams often miss, and it’s usually immediately apparent in their electrical systems if they aren’t paying attention to them.

Cut wires slightly longer than needed. You don’t want wires to be pulled too tightly, especially if you’re using zip ties or other cable management tools to route your electrical lines. You’ll also want some slack in case things change or if you need to redo connectors or strip wires again for any reason. While I’m not saying to leave a loop or bundle, a little extra slack can be helpful.

Think logically about routing wires. Avoid a chaotic tangle of random cables that would be difficult to sort through when troubleshooting. Be deliberate: bundle motors for a single submodule together in its own line; keep subsystems grouped individually; organize CAN networks based on location or subsystem, etc.

Basically, a bit of forethought and organization can make electrical systems clean and serviceable even in a rush. There are definitely more advanced things you could do, but these are typically the first steps I recommend for students entering electrical work.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked:
Do you have an electrical mentor or at least a mentor knowledgeable in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) electrical/electronic components? If so, work closely with them. Tug test everything! Practice wire stripping and crimping. Avoid bundling power cables with communication cables. Look at the Chief Delphi (CD) forum for wiring diagrams. Download all documentation for electronic components. Think about organizing wire runs before running them. Read the game manual for minimum wire gauges and connections. Those resources should suffice.  

Here’s the link to the updated control system diagrams: [2025 Unofficial FRC Control System Diagrams](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/2025-unofficial-frc-control-system-diagrams/476263).

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: To add onto what others said, being able to navigate the REV Hardware Client and Phoenix Tuner is very useful for diagnosing errors. Additionally, it's important to understand the meanings of status LEDs, particularly differentiating between "no CAN" and "good CAN" states.

posts.name: Maaz_Hawa
posts.cooked: Par. On our robot this past year our motors were very spread out and finding a specific set of power wires through a wire highway was not pleasant. We zip tied most of our power wire sets together to maintain organization but this caused problems when we needed to locate a specific wire set back to the PDH REV's Power Distribution Hub. Since you appear knowledgeable how do you bundle wires for each motor or motor set individually while keeping things organized Also do you have a picture of your robot's wiring that I could reference

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Do a tug-test on each wire right after making every connection (screw terminal, push button terminal, lever nut, solder joint, etc). Tug-test each wire in a pair separately because if one wire is secure and the other isn't, the pair may seem secure.

Read the documentation for all control system components to determine the appropriate lengths for all connectors used.

Work out the routing of wires (bundles) by taking screenshots of the 3D CAD from various angles and then drawing them using a drawing tool, using different colors for high-current, low-current, and signal wires.

Do not tighten the zip ties too much when securing wire bundles; slight movement allows for better wire tracing. Excessive tightening can make it impossible to trace wires.

Treat the control system as a subsystem in the robot and reserve space for it early in the robot's design process. Enforce proper planning for electrical components like the battery, main breaker, radio, and others. Regularly review the CAD design by someone from the electrical group to prevent blocked access and ensure component placement makes sense.

Prioritize reducing wire length, especially for those connecting from the battery SB-50 to the main breaker towards PDH/PDH or PDP and back to SB-50.

Design control system parts for installation on sub-panels that can be assembled in parallel with the robot chassis assembly. Some basic pre-tests on the control system might be feasible before installing sub-panels.

Select individuals with good attention to detail and workmanship for the electrical team through methods like mechanical training. This approach ensures a reliable control system, as previous teams have achieved without major issues.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
I wrote this a number of years ago. Some of the control system components have changed since then, but most of the suggestions still apply. (Ignore the title, it was a thing at the time)  
If this is going to be a thing, then let’s keep it going. This is following on similar posts about scouting, programming, defense, and being rookies. Hi, I’m Ari. I was in charge of electronics on my high school team, mentor the electronics sub-team on my current team, and have been volunteering as a CSA for 3 years (with 15 competitions as a CSA under my belt). I’ve seen my fair share of robots dying from all kinds of electronics problems. Here are some of the more common ones that might be…

link_counts.title: Your Team Sucks At Electronics: Here's Why

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
My advice is to label both ends of your power wires for the PDH. Since you're likely bundling them together, having one person ready with a label maker equipped with heat-shrink labels will help organize the wiring efficiently.  
CAN is its own complex system, and we usually only label components when they become particularly intricate.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: Red to red, black to black!

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: This is an extremely important point: FRC components do not smell good when red is connected to black.

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
In general, a goal should be to have every connector restrained on the robot, either using zip tie squares or some of these helpful alternatives. Hot glue is beneficial for relieving strain on connectors, but it should not be used excessively. To address any issues, you can apply 99% iso alcohol to remove glue effectively. When using powerpoles, ensure that anyone handling them has sufficient experience with proper crimping techniques, as it can be less straightforward than inspecting products like WAGOS, where visual checks are more reliable. Always follow instructions carefully regarding crimping and visual inspections.

For can connections, consider using solder or molex sl. Molex sl has proven effective for hot-swappable connectors. Avoid using double crimped JST connectors with Spark Maxes; instead, crimp your own connections or use Thriftbot connectors.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: I lent my team my Brother D410 label maker because it enables creating a spreadsheet of labels that can be printed with a few clicks. The label maker connects to a laptop running free Brother software, though not all models support this feature. This tool simplifies generating multiple distinct labels. Our labels replicate the professional quality produced by workplace label makers, though they are wrapped individually.

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked:
The text is:  
The red and blue boxes represent both front end swerve drive lines, the green represents one side of our pivoting controls for out pivoting elevator.  Normally this would be labeled in robot, but this was done in such a rush we didn't have time to place that in this season (wiring was completed like 3 days prior to our first regional). We also run a stacked electronics board which can definitely introduce some headache, running cable in a logical manner keeps it from being too bad for maintenance. It also protects cables from external faults while also making the electrical look cleaner from the outside. Another example of wire packaging from the module side. The wire in the foreground is one of the previously mentioned pivot motor runs but is packaged separately from the module for easy troubleshooting. Honestly, this isn't the cleanest set of cable runs for us, but it's definitely better than a bird's nest and allows us to quickly troubleshoot electrical issues on the fly. It's just unfortunate I can't lift the stack to show the underside wire runs without removing the entire elevator assembly.

posts.name: Daniel Herring
posts.cooked: CONNECTIONS BETWEEN CAN WAGOS AND HARD IMPACTS RESULT IN DEAD ROBOTS ON FIELD

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CAD subordinate and Drive team/Pit Crew member, also Enby

posts.name: Calvin Hou
posts.cooked: I had no issues wiring can through Wago 221 inlines last year both on the rio bus and the canivore FD bus. I think the key part to doing them is just using ferrules. Our robot definitely had some pretty hard impacts and had no electrical issues throughout the season.

posts.name: Daniel Herring
posts.cooked: For an experienced wiring team, efficiency is key, but for a team like ours in location 23, where members may lack experience, taking unnecessary risks by manually soldering and heat-shrinking wires—even though it only takes 5 minutes—is unwise. We’ve never encountered a broken soldered wire on our team. Additionally, WAGOs prove invaluable when early-stage routing allows for simple adjustments.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CAD subordinate and Drive team/Pit Crew member, also Enby

posts.name: Calvin Hou
posts.cooked: Our wiring in 24 was entirely done by me, and it was my first robot I had ever fully wired. Soldering is significantly easier to mess up, especially with heatshrink. If there’s any failure under that, you’ll have an enjoyable time tracking it down. The near-impossible difficulty in messing up ferrules and wagos, given you strip enough wire and use a decent ferrule crimper, makes this process much simpler.

posts.name: Daniel Herring
posts.cooked: "fair enough"

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CAD subordinate and Drive team/Pit Crew member, also Enby

posts.name: George Horsey
posts.cooked:
Plan the Route  
Collaborate with the design team to plan where wires will be routed. While we don’t typically place wires in CAD, we measure the model and compare the available space to real-world wire bundles to visualize routing paths during the design phase.  

Group Similar Wires  
Group power wires separately from data/signal wires. This organization reduces strain, especially on CAN wiring—critical for SparkMax JST CAN connectors.  

Inspect and Test Crimps  
Visually inspect each crimp and perform a pull test. We supervise the first few crimps for any connector, and if they meet spec, we keep one as a reference. If a crimp is poor, we provide direct feedback for correction. Every connection gets a few sharp tugs to ensure it’s properly seated and clipped in. For PowerPole connectors, we add a zip tie once they’re fully landed to keep them secure.  

Label and Pair Wires  
Cable wrap-style labels are ideal. Even a simple tape flag with a number helps identify wire pairs—saving time when using a multimeter. Zip ties or plastic cable wrap (where space allows) along each wire pair’s route keep things neat and organized.  

Use Grommets When Passing Through Metal  
Anytime wires pass through the robot frame or metal parts, use grommets to prevent abrasion.  

Avoid Ferrules for Weidmuller Terminals  
Ferrules can interfere with Weidmuller connections (like on the VRM, PCM, or Vivid Hosting radio), as the colored boots sometimes press the release button. In these cases, we lightly tin the ends of the wire instead.  

Minimize Soldering  
Avoid soldering where possible. We allow it only for PCB connections and when tinning wire ends for Weidmuller terminals. Soldered wires become brittle at the solder-to-copper transition—often under insulation—making breaks harder to diagnose. When tinning, we keep solder only at the tip to hold strands together without letting it wick under the insulation.  

Use WAGO Connectors Appropriately  
WAGO connectors are more reliable with larger gauge wires. Smaller wires—even with ferrules—can slip out if the lever is bumped, so take care in those cases.  

Use Fir Tree Clips for Cable Management  
Fir tree clips are a great solution for clean cable routing.  

Limit Igus Chain Length  
Igus chains work best in short lengths unless held under tension. Longer sections tend to whip around and can snap at the joints during robot motion.  

Color Code Power Wires  
Use red for positive and black (or another consistent color) for negative throughout the robot to quickly identify polarity and avoid mistakes.  

Double Check Device Voltages  
Ensure the correct voltage before connecting devices to power. FRC has a mix of mostly 5v and 12v devices.  

Use Consistent CAN Layout  
Keep your CAN bus daisy-chained in a logical order (e.g., front-to-back or drivetrain-to-subsystems), and clearly mark the start and end points with 120-ohm terminators where required.  

Leave Service Loops  
Leave small service loops near connections to allow for movement, strain relief, and easy replacement—particularly in tight or high-vibration areas.  

Secure Battery Cables Separately  
Battery leads should be firmly secured and isolated from signal wiring to avoid disconnection and EMI noise.  

Use a Multimeter Regularly During Builds  
Verify continuity, voltage, and polarity at multiple points during the wiring process—not just at the end.  

Document Wiring Layouts  
Take photos or create diagrams of wire routing and connections for easier troubleshooting and repair during competitions.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: Teaching them general skills such as crimping, selecting appropriate connectors, wiring techniques, and diagnosing issues related to the CAN Controller Area Network has proven beneficial. Additionally, guiding them through building a complete robot and subsequently analyzing areas for improvement in terms of reliability and cleanliness has been particularly effective.
